facts.text: Field No. 1129/477 measuring five bighas and thirteen biswas situated in Kilokri was an evacuee property under the management of the managing officer.
The property was acquired by the Central Government under the Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954.
The property was sold by public auction on January 2, 1961 and purchased by PW 17 Ashwani Kumar Dutt for Rs. 7,600.
Provisional delivery of the property was given to PW 17 on October 10, 1961 (also stated as October 12, 1961).
Sale certificate was issued to PW 17 on February 8, 1962 (Exh. PF).
Actual delivery of the property was given to PW 17 on June 22, 1962 as per warrant issued by PW 5 Khushi Ram, managing officer, effected by PW 11 Sham Das Kanungo.

At the time of delivery on June 22, 1962, Jamuna (DW 3) was not present; no evidence he was aware; crops grown by Jamuna were on a portion of the field, valued at Rs. 60 and deposited by PW 17 with PW 5 for Jamuna; some ploughing done as token.

Jamuna (DW 3) had been tenant of the field for over thirty years under Muslim landlords and then managing officer; tenancy never terminated; raised crops; evidence supported by prosecution exh. PT; unchallenged in cross-examination.

On June 30, 1962 (day prior to occurrence), PW 17 and PW 19 R.P. Dutt met Jamuna, asked for compromise and peaceful delivery; Jamuna said he was going out of station and would consider after return; they threatened to take possession by force with police pressure.
On July 1, 1962, PW 17, PW 19 R.P. Dutt, PW 16 Gopal Das, PW 15 Nand Lal and B.N. Acharya (tractor driver) went to the field with tractor to level the land; PW 19 armed with unlicensed pistol.

Appellants, near relations of Jamuna, came armed with spears and lathis, asked complainant party to clear out; when refused, pushed them and used force, injuring PW 17, PW 19 and B.N. Acharya (simple injuries).
Appellants denied presence and causing injuries in s.342 Cr.P.C. statements but pleaded private defence throughout.
No visits to field by complainant or men between June 22 and July 1, 1962.
Police assistance obtained at time of delivery on June 22, 1962.
Courts below accepted prosecution version on possession and incident; convicted appellants under ss. 447, 324 r/w 149 and 148 IPC.
Appeal by special leave from Punjab High Court judgment and order dated April 26, 1965 in Criminal Revision No. 266-D of 1964.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellants have established satisfactorily the right of private defence pleaded by them.
If they had that right, have they exceeded the same?
Who was in possession of the field on July 1, 1962?
Was the delivery of the field on June 22, 1962 lawful?

petitioner_arguments.text: Jamuna was tenant for over 30 years, tenancy never terminated, continued in possession even after alleged delivery which was without authority of law and of no effect.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Displaced Persons Act 1954; no termination of tenancy; no authority for managing officer to evict post-sale

petitioner_arguments.text: On day prior, PW17 and PW19 tried to intimidate Jamuna for compromise; on July 1, complainant party came forcibly with tractor and pistol to assert possession; appellants asked them to leave, then used minimum force.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Right of private defence of property under ss. 97, 99 IPC

respondent_arguments.text: PW17 took possession on June 22, 1962 via delivery; Jamuna should have agitated grievances in court; appellants had no right to take law into hands.
Delivery effected under s.19 of Displaced Persons Act 1954.
Enough time between June 22 and July 1 to seek public authorities' protection.

court_reasoning.text: Jamuna in possession till June 22 as tenant for 30 years, unchallenged; no termination of tenancy; government sold property Jan 1961, no interest post-sale; managing officer had no authority to evict tenant or issue delivery warrant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tenant cannot be evicted without terminating tenancy via competent court; managing officer powerless post-sale.

court_reasoning.text: Delivery on June 22 invalid: Jamuna absent/unaware; crops standing; no action under s.19(1)(2); s.19(3) requires prior steps; paper delivery only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Purported delivery has no legal force; Jamuna continued in possession.

court_reasoning.text: PW17/PW19 conscious Jamuna in possession (threats June 30, police at delivery); no visits June 22-July 1; July 1 entry with tractor/pistol = criminal trespass and unlawful assembly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Complainant party trespassed; appellants defended possession.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants unaware of delivery (not present, no notice); sudden invasion on July 1; no time to seek authorities; right of private defence liberal; force not excessive (simple injuries after asking to leave).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Did not exceed right; trespasser not in settled possession.

holdings.text: Jamuna continued in possession on July 1, 1962; delivery invalid.
Appellants established right of private defence of property against criminal trespass; did not exceed it.
True possessor (Jamuna/appellants) entitled to defend against trespassers not in settled possession using necessary force.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Jogali Bhaigo Naiks and another
precedents_cited.relevance: Court may consider plea of private defence even if not specifically pleaded if arises from record.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lallu Yeshwant Singh v. Rao Jagdish Singh and others
precedents_cited.relevance: Tenant eviction requires termination of tenancy and court process; no self-help by landlord.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jai Dev v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Right of private defence of property liberal; no need to flee if immediate danger and state aid unavailable; force not disproportionate.
Possessor may use force to eject trespasser in process of acquiring possession.
Non-acquiescing possessor and friends not unlawful assembly when resisting armed trespassers.
Similar to above on possession defence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 447, 324/149, 148; right of private defence of property against criminal trespass.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellants' statements denying presence but plea laid in cross-exam/defence evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Purported delivery under s.19 invalid as no prior action under sub-ss.(1)(2); applies only to evacuee properties under control.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; conviction under ss.447, 324 r/w 149 and 148 IPC set aside; appellants acquitted as they acted in right of private defence without exceeding it.

key_quotes.text: The burden of establishing that plea is on the accused and that burden can be discharged by showing preponderance of probabilities in favour of that plea on the basis of the material on record.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Standard for proving private defence plea.

key_quotes.text: Normally before a tenant can be evicted from his holding, his tenancy must be terminated and the eviction should be done through a court of competent jurisdiction. No landlord has any right to throw out his tenant from his holding.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The right of private defence serves a social purpose and that right should be liberally construed. Such a right not only will be a restraining influence on bad characters but it will encourage the right spirit in a free citizen.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the conviction of the appellants is set aside and they are acquitted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
